Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2008 03:23PM TrixieTumor wrote: Deb,  Big hugs! This is a tough decision.  I wish I could help you with a personal story, but that wasn't my regimen. My suggestion on where to start is pubmed.gov, a searchable database of articles from medical journals. You often get only the summary, but a good library (university, especially) can help you find full articles. Sometimes the summary is enough since it usually includes some type of conclusion.  You never know how you'll react to a regimen. There's always a chance you won't find that the side effects are twice as bad. I do think it helps to be prepared for the worst, though. Stock up on Ativan, Ambien, Percoset, and whatever else will take you into never-neverland. Narcotics are a chemo girl's best friend. TT

Posts.Content: TrixieTumor wrote: I need to vent. I think my oncologist is excellent, but I spend more time with the nurses and schedulers than I do with the doctor. And I've reached a point where I hate them. Somewhere along the line I got labeled a troublesome patient, I think. I wish I knew what in particular I did, but I did something because the staff's attitude has changed from helpful to hostile. Now whenever I go to the office -- which is quite often since I'm on a weekly infusion schedule -- I face a dismissive attitude during my pre-treatment check-up. The latest fiasco came today when I reported my rising level of joint and muscle pain from Abraxane. Evidently Abraxane doesn't cause muscle pain, the nurse informed me, because "we don't see that side effect in this office." I am proud that I didn't scream at her, "So you're saying that the manufacturer is a big fat liar because it's listed as a side effect in its literature." Then she wrapped up with a little ditty about how I should keep reporting these small little things rather than diagnosing myself. I've started a Charm Offensive on the staff to try to turn this around. Weekly baked goods and a relentlessly polite and positive attitude are my weapons of choice. But what I really want to do is stab them repeatedly with an IV needle until they GET IT! Thanks for listening, TT  Dx 10/29/2007, IDC, 1cm, Stage IB, Grade 3, 0/6 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2008 01:40AM TrixieTumor wrote: Joyce, Abraxane and Taxol are the same medicine, with different delivery mechanisms. To quote from Medline Plus, "One form of paclitaxel (Abraxane) is manufactured with human albumin, and the other form of paclitaxel (Taxol) is manufactured with a solvent called Cremophor EL (polyoxyethylated castor oil)." http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/medmaster/a607070.html Since they have the same active ingredient, they should be equally effective.   Cheers, TT
